awd_titl_txt: Physics-Constrained Deep Learning for Surrogate Modeling of Dynamics of Fluids and Fluid-Structure Interaction
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop an innovative modeling framework for coupled dynamics of fluid-structure systems based on deep learning, which will contribute new knowledge on rapid modeling of dynamic systems in general. Complex fluids and their interactions with surrounding structures are ubiquitous in natural and industrial processes, e.g., blood flows in compliant vessels, flapping-wing miniature air vehicles, flexible risers in the offshore industry. Predictive modeling of fluid-structure interaction problems is of great significance in numerous engineering applications. However, existing models are primarily based on first-principles methods and numerical discretization techniques, which are computationally expensive and require significant domain expertise. This drawback poses great challenges to real-time predictions (e.g., clinical diagnosis of vascular diseases) and many-query applications (e.g., optimization design of aircraft and uncertainty quantification in high-consequence systems). This grant will support fundamental research on the development of a novel modeling framework by leveraging recent advances in machine learning and prior knowledge of physical principles. This new approach will enable rapid modeling and fast prediction for dynamics of fluid-structure systems, which will have strong practical impacts on a broad spectrum of real-world problems, including cardiovascular diagnosis, aerodynamic design, and active flow control. Therefore, the results of this research can help enhance U.S. healthcare/wellness, national security, and economic competitiveness. Moreover, the multi-disciplinary research topics across physical modeling and artificial intelligence can stimulate interest in the STEM disciplines among young people and thus will have a positive impact on science and engineering education.

Data-based surrogate modeling is a computationally feasible way to tackle fluid-structure interaction problems that require rapid predictions or repeated model evaluations. Deep learning is becoming a popular surrogate modeling approach due to its capability of handling strong nonlinearity and high dimensionality. However, current success of deep learning in the computer science community heavily relies on large-scale labeled data, which are usually not available in the physical modeling community. To address this challenge, this research aims to pioneer a physics-constrained deep learning framework for surrogate modeling of fluid-structure interaction dynamics, which will enable efficient learning with sparse training data. Specifically, a structured deep neural network will be devised to encode the initial and boundary conditions, and the governing equations will be imposed during the training by redesigning the loss (or likelihood) functions to conform to the physics. Numerical experiments of a suite of dynamic fluid-structure interaction problems are planned to answer questions regarding the effect of adding physical constraints in deep learning and their potential in modeling complex physical systems in a parametric setting. This project tackles long-standing difficulties in surrogate modeling of complex dynamical systems with nonlinearity, high-dimensionality, and data scarcity, and contributes to the modeling of dynamical systems in general. The learning framework will bring revolutionary impacts on data-driven surrogate modeling by shifting the paradigm from black-box, data-intensive learning to physics-constrained, data-scarce learning.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NOTRE DAME DU LAC

por.por_cntn:
Our project aimed to revolutionize the traditional modeling paradigm by developing physics-informed deep learning frameworks for predictive modeling of complex systems with real-time decision-making capabilities. Our work focused on fluid dynamics as a key application area, which has widespread implications for industries such as aircraft design, surgical planning, and disaster early-warning.

Over the course of the project, we achieved significant milestones and made several key contributions to the field of physics-informed deep learning. We designed novel learning architectures for learning steady and dynamic fluid systems in a parametric setting. We also proposed new techniques that can handle fluid problems with complex and irregular geometries using graph-based learning and coordinate transformation. Our project made important advancements in applying physics-informed learning to solve inverse problems in cardiovascular modeling, which enables us to infer near wall information based on sparse observation and super-resolve flow fields without high-resolution labels.

One of our major accomplishments was the development of a physics-informed fully-connected neural network for solving canonical partial differential equations, including the heat equation, burgers equation, and the Navier-Stokes equations. This is the first attempt to solve the Navier-Stokes equations with structured deep neural networks purely based on physics constraints. Another significant contribution was the proposal of a physics-constrained Bayesian deep learning framework that enables efficient Bayesian learning and accounts for uncertainties in the data. This approach is able to reconstruct the flow field with estimated uncertainties, particularly when data are corrupted with measurement noise.

Our project also proposed a novel physics-constrained convolutional neural network (CNN) architecture that can learn solutions of parametric partial differential equations on irregular domains without any labeled data. We demonstrated the effectiveness of this approach by solving a number of steady-state PDEs on irregular domains, including heat equations, Navier-Stokes equations, and Poisson equations with parameterized boundary conditions, varying geometries, and spatially-varying source fields.

We also developed a physics-informed model-based reinforcement learning framework, where governing equations and physical constraints are used to inform the model learning and policy search. By incorporating the prior information of the environment, the quality of the learned model can be notably improved, leading to better sample efficiency and learning performance.

In addition to our technical accomplishments, we also made important contributions to educational and STEM resource development. We trained graduate and undergraduate students in deep learning and computational fluid dynamics, providing them with valuable skills and opportunities to present their research at major conferences. We have published more than 20 journal papers, given multiple invited seminar talks, and conference presentations. This project has supported two PhD students who successfully defended their dissertations.

Overall, our project has made significant contributions to the field of physics-informed deep learning, with important implications for industries and applications beyond fluid dynamics. By developing new techniques and architectures that integrate physics constraints with deep learning, we have paved the way for faster and more predictive simulations of complex systems, leading to real-time decision-making and improved design processes.

 


Last Modified: 05/01/2023
Modified by: Jian-Xun Wang
